triplet_1026_question.question: Do you think the current tariff policy under the Trump administration will have a positive or negative impact on the overall U.S. economy and society? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_1026_question.text:
[Question]

Do you think the current tariff policy under the Trump administration will have a positive or negative impact on the overall U.S. economy and society?
triplet_1026_question.displayed_text:
[Question]

Do you think the current tariff policy under the Trump administration will have a positive or negative impact on the overall U.S. economy and society?

triplet_1026_rating.question: Do you think the current tariff policy under the Trump administration will have a positive or negative impact on the overall U.S. economy and society? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_1026_rating.text:
Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Sentiment skews negative: roughly 75% view the tariff policy as harmful to the U.S. economy and society, about 15% see it as beneficial, and around 10% express mixed or conditional views.
  • Most-cited negative impacts:
  • Higher consumer prices and inflation as businesses pass tariff costs through, disproportionately hurting lower- and middle-income households and small businesses.
  • Weaker international relations and the risk of retaliation (especially with China), with concerns about isolation from global trade.
  • Limited evidence of reshoring; firms may delay investment, wait out policies, or work around tariffs, leading to uncertainty and potential recession risks.
  • Supply-chain disruptions, delays, and reduced economic output or wage growth.
  • Positive arguments emphasize:
  • Protecting domestic industries, encouraging “buy American,” and potentially making U.S. products more competitive.
  • Using tariffs as leverage for better trade deals and to address perceived unfair practices.
  • Potential increases in tariff revenue and possible longer-run fiscal benefits, with some accepting short-term pain for long-term gains.
  • Mixed/conditional views:
  • Short-term negatives but possible long-term benefits if tariffs become targeted, strategic, and part of peaceful, stable negotiations.
  • Some perceive limited real-world impact due to corporate workarounds; others note benefits may accrue to certain investors while costs fall on consumers.
  • Areas of broad concern:
  • Consumer cost-of-living pressures, small-business strain, uncertainty deterring investment, and uneven distribution of costs and benefits across society.

triplet_1026_comparison.question: Do you think the current tariff policy under the Trump administration will have a positive or negative impact on the overall U.S. economy and society? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_1026_comparison.text:
Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Sentiment skews negative: roughly 75% view the tariff policy as harmful to the U.S. economy and society, about 15% see it as beneficial, and around 10% express mixed or conditional views.
  • Most-cited negative impacts:
  • Higher consumer prices and inflation as businesses pass tariff costs through, disproportionately hurting lower- and middle-income households and small businesses.
  • Weaker international relations and the risk of retaliation (especially with China), with concerns about isolation from global trade.
  • Limited evidence of reshoring; firms may delay investment, wait out policies, or work around tariffs, leading to uncertainty and potential recession risks.
  • Supply-chain disruptions, delays, and reduced economic output or wage growth.
  • Positive arguments emphasize:
  • Protecting domestic industries, encouraging “buy American,” and potentially making U.S. products more competitive.
  • Using tariffs as leverage for better trade deals and to address perceived unfair practices.
  • Potential increases in tariff revenue and possible longer-run fiscal benefits, with some accepting short-term pain for long-term gains.
  • Mixed/conditional views:
  • Short-term negatives but possible long-term benefits if tariffs become targeted, strategic, and part of peaceful, stable negotiations.
  • Some perceive limited real-world impact due to corporate workarounds; others note benefits may accrue to certain investors while costs fall on consumers.
  • Areas of broad concern:
  • Consumer cost-of-living pressures, small-business strain, uncertainty deterring investment, and uneven distribution of costs and benefits across society.

Summary B

Summary of views: - Overall sentiment skews negative. Roughly 70% view the tariff policy as harmful, about 20% see it as beneficial, and around 10% offer mixed or uncertain views.

Key negative themes: - Higher prices and inflation: Many expect businesses to pass tariff costs to consumers, squeezing household budgets and especially hurting lower- and middle-income families. - Pressure on small businesses: Several cite rising input costs, delays, and trade frictions that strain smaller firms. - Limited reshoring and investment uncertainty: Skepticism that tariffs will bring manufacturing back given dissolved supply chains; firms may delay investment amid policy unpredictability. - International fallout: Concerns about damaged relations (notably with China), retaliation, reduced free trade, and a perception of U.S. “bullying,” potentially isolating the U.S. and raising recession risks.

Key positive themes: - Long-term protection and competitiveness: Supporters think tariffs can shield strategic industries, make U.S.-made goods more competitive, and encourage “buy American.” - Fiscal and bargaining leverage: Some believe tariff revenue and tougher stances can stabilize the budget and secure better trade deals over time. - Leveling the playing field: A view that other countries have taken advantage of the U.S., and tariffs correct imbalances, even if short-term costs rise.

Mixed/conditional views: - Short-term pain, possible long-term gain if policies are consistent, targeted, and paired with broader economic strategy. - Some perceive limited real impact so far due to company workarounds. - A few cite studies projecting longer-run economic losses, underscoring uncertainty.

Bottom line: Most commenters anticipate near-term negative effects—especially higher consumer prices and strain on small businesses—with worries about trade retaliation and investment uncertainty. A minority expects potential long-run benefits for domestic industry and bargaining power if the policy is sustained, targeted, and complemented by broader measures.
